abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, though institutional
            development impacts are only modest. Lessons reinforce once
            again, the beneficial aspects of flexible projects, which as
            in this case, the continuous evolution in the interpretation
            of project objectives, permitted adaptation to radical
            changes in the policy context. Particularly in this project,
            such flexibility became an important tool for the
            project's survival in a changing political, and
            economic environment, whose highly focused monitoring, and
            evaluation criteria, adapted to the overall project
            indicators, allowing an essential, and rigorous
            post-evaluation. Moreover, the reconciliatory effect that
            projects supporting health, and social sectors can have in
            countries suffering from difficult security problems, was
            demonstrated by this project's state presence at the
            local level, responsive to people's needs, especially
            in areas with precarious security.

5079446.trustfund:
TF032308-COLOMBIA - MUNICIPAL HEALTH PROJECT,TF020400-NETHERLANDS' CONSULTANTS
            TRUST FUND,TF037678-COLOMBIA - DECENTRALIZED ED MGT
5079446.majtheme: Social protection and risk management,Urban development,Human development

abstracts.cdata!:
The project aims to strengthen
            management and provide incentives, in the form of grants, to
            support municipal provision of a basic package of primary
            health care services. The project consists of three
            components. The first component, institutional development,
            is designed to: (a) introduce a municipal health management
            information system to support planning and monitoring of
            primary health care services; and (b) provide related
            training and technical support for municipal administrative
            authorities, municipal health administrators and community
            representatives, numbering about 6,000 in the project area.
            The second component, service development is designed to:
            (a) implement municipal subprojects, to be co-financed by
            the municipalities and the central government, to support a
            basic package of primary health care services by: providing
            medical supplies and equipment; and financing
            rehabilitation, expansion, construction and furnishing of
            selected primary health care facilities; and (b) provide
            related training and technical support for some 13,000
            municipal health practitioners in the project area. The last
            component, policy development, will support the design and
            implementation of selected policy measures for introducing
            systematic pricing and cost-recovery for primary health
            services in the public system and for quality control for
            primary health care, and for strengthening employment system
            for public health personnel; and provide for an impact
            evaluation for the project.
